Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Proposal: A Data-Intensive Exploration of the Links Between SES and STEM Learning Outcomes

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The links between family SES and students' learning, in STEM and other disciplines, is well noted in the literature. However, the nature of the data that has been used for these studies is quite coarse grained and is increasingly hard to get as schools are no longer required to determine who is eligible for free and reduced-price lunch. The researchers in this project will use Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) or food stamps data utilization data as a proxy for socioeconomic status (SES) to determine the utility of such data. In addition, educators are increasingly exhorted to use data to inform decision-making, though the data available and the data representations are not always sufficient for educator use. The collaborative interaction between researchers collecting and organizing data and stakeholders who are brought together to make sense of the data provides the strong context in which better interpretations of data are supported.

The researchers in this exploratory study funded as part of the Ideas Lab for Data Intensive Research will examine the relationships among fluctuations in patterns of students' SES measured by daily transaction data using SNAP data and multiple STEM achievement, behavioral referral, and attendance outcomes. The researchers will also examine the extent to which the relationships identified can be visualized in ways that have utility to various stakeholders including school staff and those who work in youth-serving organizations. Three research questions will structure this research as follows: 1). In what ways can SNAP transaction data and student achievement data be used to explore the relationships between temporal variation in SES and STEM learning outcomes?; 2). How do stakeholders make sense of and how do they construct implications for action based on data intensive analyses and visualizations of students' time-varying SES?; and, 3). What supports do stakeholders need in order to construct implications for action and engage in collaborative data analyses? Food stamp data provided from North Carolina's Department of Health and Human Services will be integrated with data on students' data obtained from the North Carolina Education Research Data Center at Duke University. These data will be analyzed with longitudinal data analysis models, visual data analytics, and multi-level modeling techniques. Stakeholders from the Durham, North Carolina school district will include teachers, administrators and counselors from the districts' K-12 schools and youth-serving organizations. This research-practitioner collaboration will identify ways in which new data about students and new data visualizations support interpretations that enhance stakeholder's decision-making related to students' success in STEM.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to bring together researchers and practitioners around jointly analyzing data from two statewide agencies in North Carolina. We used data on children’s receipt of Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) benefits from the Division of Social Services, Department of Health and Human Services and data on childrens’ educational outcomes from the Department of Public Instruction. Both datasets were de-identified and housed at Duke University in collaboration with the North Carolina Education Research Data Center. Using iterative “cycles of inquiry” we deployed a variety of analytical techniques to explore research questions that were jointly developed between researchers and practitioners. This project brought researchers and practitioners together to (1) understand the relationships between students’ socioeconomic status (SES) and STEM learning outcomes and (2) to identify ways in which data-intensive research methods could be used to enhance stakeholders’ decision-making related to students’ success in STEM. Thus, throughout this project we sought to inform the broader research community and support practitioners’ decision-making.

 

The largest food assistance program in the U.S. and an important part of the U.S. safety net, SNAP provides cash-like benefits to low-income individuals and families. Understanding how SNAP affects children and families is crucial to both research and policy efforts aimed at supporting the healthy development of children from low-income households. To do so, researchers from Duke University’s Center for Child and Family Policy, SRI International, and Teachers College, Columbia University as well as practitioners from the Durham County Department of Social Services and the North Carolina Department of Public Instruction worked together and in various combinations throughout this project.

 

In many projects, research is “done to” children, families, and program administrators as opposed to “done with” these constituencies. This is also the case in less interventionist approaches where researchers seek to work with and analyze administrative data from social services agencies, schools or districts. More often than not, data are collected and analyzed to answer researchers’ questions. This approach can and has served the research enterprise well but often does not provide as much value to those working directly with children. For the current project, we hypothesized that attending to the needs of practitioners at the outset could lead to better, more actionable data analyses for local policymakers as well as add nuance and context to researchers’ own questions related to the links between SES and STEM learning outcomes.

 

Both researchers and practitioners offer unique insights into issues facing children and a guiding principle of this project was that administrative data could serve as a tool for engaging in collaborative problem solving. Because practitioners in different agencies are not typically able to utilize data from other agencies and because there are often barriers to cross-agency data linkage, we as researchers were uniquely positioned to provide practitioners with access to and unique juxtapositions of data that they would not otherwise encounter. We brought researchers and practitioners together to (1) develop research questions, (2) create data products that responded to a question, (3) jointly interpret data products, and (4) co-develop implications to support future action taking.

 

The project successfully launched and completed three cycles of inquiry that followed the above fours steps. The first cycle of inquiry involved researchers from Duke, SRI, and Teachers College combining data related to students’ SNAP status and learning outcomes on statewide standardized end-of-grade (EOG) scores in reading and math. Preliminary analyses were presented to practitioners from Durham County Social Services, Durham School Board, Durham County Public Health, Durham Public Schools, and the East Durham Children’s Initiative. The second cycle of inquiry built on the first and examined data from Durham County Social Services (DCSS) in an effort to test practitioner-developed hypotheses related to children’s interactions with the Child Protective Services (CPS) system. While many practitioners who attended the first cycle of inquiry recognized the myriad ways in which SES was related to student achievement, DCSS staff wanted to understand differences in EOG performances for students who had an unsubstantiated versus a substantiated report of abuse or neglect. The third cycle of inquiry, built on observations from the first and second cycles in analyzing the multifaceted nature of economic need by exploring the relationship between SES and behavioral infractions in schools and the combined relationship between SNAP status and behavioral infractions on student achievement.

 

Across these cycles, we benefited our practitioner partners as well as identified lessons learned for subsequent research-practice partnerships. Examples of these lessons include coming to fully understand the entire process by which data is entered into an administrative system, working to identify questions that implicate all participating practitioners, cultivating regular meetings and interactions among partnership members, and being strategic on selecting research questions that are beneficial to both researchers and practitioners.


Last Modified: 09/22/2017
Modified by: Anna Gassman-Pines
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The goal of this project was to bring together researchers and practitioners around jointly analyzing data from two statewide agencies in North Carolina. We used data on children?s receipt of Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) benefits from the Division of Social Services, Department of Health and Human Services and data on childrens? educational outcomes from the Department of Public Instruction. Both datasets were de-identified and housed at Duke University in collaboration with the North Carolina Education Research Data Center. Using iterative "cycles of inquiry" we deployed a variety of analytical techniques to explore research questions that were jointly developed between researchers and practitioners. This project brought researchers and practitioners together to (1) understand the relationships between students? socioeconomic status (SES) and STEM learning outcomes and (2) to identify ways in which data-intensive research methods could be used to enhance stakeholders? decision-making related to students? success in STEM. Thus, throughout this project we sought to inform the broader research community and support practitioners? decision-making. The largest food assistance program in the U.S. and an important part of the U.S. safety net, SNAP provides cash-like benefits to low-income individuals and families. Understanding how SNAP affects children and families is crucial to both research and policy efforts aimed at supporting the healthy development of children from low-income households. To do so, researchers from Duke University?s Center for Child and Family Policy, SRI International, and Teachers College, Columbia University as well as practitioners from the Durham County Department of Social Services and the North Carolina Department of Public Instruction worked together and in various combinations throughout this project. In many projects, research is "done to" children, families, and program administrators as opposed to "done with" these constituencies. This is also the case in less interventionist approaches where researchers seek to work with and analyze administrative data from social services agencies, schools or districts. More often than not, data are collected and analyzed to answer researchers? questions. This approach can and has served the research enterprise well but often does not provide as much value to those working directly with children. For the current project, we hypothesized that attending to the needs of practitioners at the outset could lead to better, more actionable data analyses for local policymakers as well as add nuance and context to researchers? own questions related to the links between SES and STEM learning outcomes. Both researchers and practitioners offer unique insights into issues facing children and a guiding principle of this project was that administrative data could serve as a tool for engaging in collaborative problem solving. Because practitioners in different agencies are not typically able to utilize data from other agencies and because there are often barriers to cross-agency data linkage, we as researchers were uniquely positioned to provide practitioners with access to and unique juxtapositions of data that they would not otherwise encounter. We brought researchers and practitioners together to (1) develop research questions, (2) create data products that responded to a question, (3) jointly interpret data products, and (4) co-develop implications to support future action taking. The project successfully launched and completed three cycles of inquiry that followed the above fours steps. The first cycle of inquiry involved researchers from Duke, SRI, and Teachers College combining data related to students? SNAP status and learning outcomes on statewide standardized end-of-grade (EOG) scores in reading and math. The second cycle of inquiry built on the first and examined data from Durham County Social Services (DCSS) in an effort to test practitioner-developed hypotheses related to children?s interactions with the Child Protective Services (CPS) system. While many practitioners who attended the first cycle of inquiry recognized the myriad ways in which SES was related to student achievement, DCSS staff wanted to understand differences in EOG performances for students who had an unsubstantiated versus a substantiated report of abuse or neglect. The third cycle of inquiry, built on observations from the first and second cycles in analyzing the multifaceted nature of economic need by exploring the relationship between SES and behavioral infractions in schools and the combined relationship between SNAP status and behavioral infractions on student achievement. Examples of these lessons include coming to fully understand the entire process by which data is entered into an administrative system, working to identify questions that implicate all participating practitioners, cultivating regular meetings and interactions among partnership members, and being strategic on selecting research questions that are beneficial to both researchers and practitioners.
